title: Saheb Sarbib
text:
Saheb Sarbib (born 1944) is an American <a href="jazz">jazz</a> double-bassist and <a href="bandleader">bandleader</a>.
Career.
Sarbib, born Jean Henri Sarbib, was raised in Europe. His father was <a href="Roger%20Sarbib">Roger Sarbib</a>, a French pianist and innovator of the big band style in Portugal in the 1940s and 1950s, who also played piano behind French singers such as <a href="Edith%20Piaf">Edith Piaf</a>, <a href="Charles%20Trenet">Charles Trenet</a> and <a href="Maurice%20Chevalier">Maurice Chevalier</a>. From 1973–1977 Sarbib led his own ensembles in France; <a href="Daunik%20Lazro">Daunik Lazro</a>, <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Jeanneau">François Jeanneau</a>, <a href="Muhammad%20Ali%20%28drummer%29">Muhammad Ali</a>, and <a href="Mino%20Cin%C3%A9lu">Mino Cinélu</a> were among those who played with him as sidemen. In Europe he performed with <a href="Cecil%20Taylor">Cecil Taylor</a> and <a href="Archie%20Shepp">Archie Shepp</a>.
In 1977, Sarbib moved to New York City, where he led small groups and established the Saheb Sarbib Multinational Big Band, with sidemen including <a href="Roy%20Campbell%2C%20Jr.">Roy Campbell</a>, <a href="Jack%20Walrath">Jack Walrath</a>, <a href="Art%20Baron">Art Baron</a>, <a href="Talib%20Kibwe">Talib Kibwe</a>, <a href="Pete%20Chavez">Pete Chavez</a>, <a href="Joe%20Ford%20%28musician%29">Joe Ford</a>, <a href="Jemeel%20Moondoc">Jemeel Moondoc</a>, <a href="Richard%20Baratta">Richard Baratta</a>, <a href="Mark%20Whitecage">Mark Whitecage</a>, <a href="Dave%20Hofstra">Dave Hofstra</a>, <a href="Guilherme%20Franco">Guilherme Franco</a>, <a href="Booker%20T.%20Williams">Booker T. Williams</a>, and the saxophonist <a href="Joe%20Lovano">Joe Lovano</a>. <a href="Paul%20Nebenzahl">Paul Nebenzahl</a> helped arrange his charts. Sarbib also performed with <a href="Paul%20Motian">Paul Motian</a>, <a href="Rashied%20Ali">Rashied Ali</a>, <a href="Hal%20Galper">Hal Galper</a> and <a href="Kirk%20Lightsey">Kirk Lightsey</a> in New York City nightclubs in the late 1970s.
Saheb also played double bass for saxophonist <a href="Archie%20Shepp">Archie Shepp</a> including his 1984 album "Down Home New York" alongside <a href="Charles%20McGhee">Charles McGhee</a> on trumpet, <a href="Kenny%20Werner">Kenny Werner</a> on piano, and <a href="Marvin%20%26quot%3BSmitty%26quot%3B%20Smith">Marvin "Smitty" Smith</a> on drums.
He collaborated with the Portuguese avant-garde ensemble <a href="Telectu">Telectu</a>, playing several times with the duo, including the first edition of the Festival de Jazz de Lisboa. In 1989 the group recorded "Encounters II//Labirintho 7.8" with Saheb.
Sarbib disappeared from music in the late 1980s. He is an art and antique dealer in New York.
Discography.
